instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the investigation for preoperative differentiation and prognosis of patients with brain metastases (MET), low-grade glioma (LGG), and high-grade glioma (HGG)?
Output: The investigation used multivoxel proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy (1H-MRS) spectra for preoperative differentiation and prognosis of patients with brain metastases (MET), low-grade glioma (LGG), and high-grade glioma (HGG).

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the study of multivoxel proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy (1H-MRS) biometrics for preoperative differentiation and prognosis of patients with brain metastases (MET), low-grade glioma (LGG), and high-grade glioma (HGG)?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods used in the study were logistic regression, receiver operating characteristic analysis, and Kaplan-Meier survival analysis.

instruction: What metric was chosen and how far can this metric go in the investigation of multivoxel proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy (1H-MRS) biometrics for preoperative differentiation and prognosis of patients with brain metastases (MET), low-grade glioma (LGG), and high-grade glioma (HGG)?
Output: The metric chosen in the investigation of multivoxel proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy (1H-MRS) biometrics for preoperative differentiation and prognosis of patients with brain metastases (MET), low-grade glioma (LGG), and high-grade glioma (HGG) was the neurochemical profiles of various metabolites. These metabolites included N-acetyl aspartate (NAA) + NAAG (NAA), Cr + PCr (total creatine, tCr), Glu + Gln (Glx), lactate (Lac), myo-inositol (Ins), GPC + PCho (total choline, tCho), and total lipids, and macromolecule (tMM) signals. The concentrations of these metabolites were reported as absolute concentrations or ratios to tCho or tCr levels. This metric was used to assess the differences and prognostic value of these metabolites in differentiating and predicting outcomes for patients with brain metastases, low-grade glioma, and high-grade glioma.

instruction: Can multivoxel proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy (1H-MRS) biometrics be considered superior to traditional methods for preoperative differentiation and prognosis of patients with brain metastases (MET), low-grade glioma (LGG), and high-grade glioma (HGG)?
Output: Multivoxel proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy (1H-MRS) biometrics can be considered superior to traditional methods for preoperative differentiation and prognosis of patients with brain metastases (MET), low-grade glioma (LGG), and high-grade glioma (HGG). The past study found that 1H-MRS imaging data, specifically the neurochemical profiles of certain metabolites, were able to provide prognostic information for overall survival (OS) in patients with HGG, LGG, and MET. Additionally, the combination of different biometrics yielded high sensitivity and specificity for differentiating between HGG/LGG and LGG/MET. These findings suggest that multivoxel 1H-MRSI can provide valuable information for preoperative differentiation and prognosis in these patients.
